abstract: Current models for the Moon's formation have yet to fully account for the thermal evolution of the Moon in the presence of H2O and other volatiles. Of particular importance is chlorine, since most lunar samples are characterised by unique heavy δ37Cl values, significantly deviating from those of other planetary materials, including Earth, for which δ37Cl values cluster around ∼0‰. In order to unravel the cause(s) of the Moon's unique chlorine isotope signature, we performed a comprehensive study of high-precision in situ Cl isotope measurements of apatite from a suite of Apollo samples with a range of geochemical characteristics and petrologic types. The Cl-isotopic compositions measured in lunar apatite in the studied samples display a wide range of δ37Cl values (reaching a maximum value of +36‰), which are positively correlated with the amount of potassium (K), Rare Earth Element (REE) and phosphorous (P) (KREEP) component in each sample. Using these new data, integrated with existing H-isotope data obtained for the same samples, we are able to place these findings in the context of the canonical lunar magma ocean (LMO) model. The results are consistent with the urKREEP reservoir being characterised by a δ37Cl ∼+30‰. Such a heavy Cl isotope signature requires metal-chloride degassing from a Cl-enriched urKREEP LMO residue, a process likely to have been triggered by at least one large crust-breaching impact event that facilitated the transport and exposure of urKREEP liquid to the lunar surface.

author_highlights.sentence: We have analysed apatite in a diverse range of lunar samples.
Cl-isotopic compositions of lunar apatite range from ∼+2 to ∼+36‰.
Lunar samples acquired heavy δ37Cl values from variable interaction with urKREEP.
Differentiation of the Moon via the LMO results in an urKREEP layer rich in Cl.
urKREEP degassed following enrichment by a crust-puncturing impact event(s).

body_text.sentence: We did not observe a relationship between apatite crystal size and petrographic setting, and apatite occurs as subhedral hexagonal to tabular crystals of up to ∼90 μm in length.
body_text.title: Petrographic context of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: In thin-section 70035,195, apatite crystals 15 and 17 both occur as basal sections (hexagonal) of ∼20 μm in diameter (Fig. 3H and 3I).
body_text.title: Petrographic context of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: Similarly, basaltic rocks originating from KREEP-poor LMO source regions characterised by lighter δ37Cl values are associated with positive bulk-rock ε143Nd initial values >2–3 (Fig. 8B and Supplementary Table 2).

body_text.sentence: This hypothesis could be tested through future sample return missions that target regions on the lunar surface far outside the PKT region.

body_text.sentence: In lunar rocks, apatite [Ca5(PO4)3(F,Cl,OH)] is the most common volatile-bearing mineral (McCubbin et al., 2015a).
body_text.title: Introduction

body_text.sentence: Our sample set covers a range of lunar lithological types, including KREEP and very high potassium (VHK) basalts, and selected plutonic highlands rocks (full details can be found in the Supplementary Information).
body_text.title: Introduction

body_text.sentence: Most of the apatite observed are subhedral and are usually heavily fractured (Fig. 4B).
body_text.title: Petrographic context of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: Based on the work of Fegley (1991), in which thermodynamic activities of volatiles under lunar conditions were considered, he concluded that the dominant species likely to be degassed when H/Cl <1 were HCl and HF in the case of H species and metal chlorides (and fluoride species) as the dominant species carrying the halogens.
body_text.title: LMO degassing and vapour speciation: Implications for H-isotopes

body_text.sentence: In addition, Canup et al. (2015) have recently provided possible mechanisms to explain some isotopic differences between these two bodies (e.g., Zn).
body_text.title: Introduction

body_text.sentence: Twenty eight apatite grains were identified as being suitable for analysis by ion probe (see below).
body_text.title: Analytical protocols

body_text.sentence: The degassed metal chlorides would be drawn into cold traps (i.e., regions of the surface surrounding the melt pool that would be substantially cooler than the melt) in the surrounding crust and regolith where the metal chloride vapour would condense back into chloride salts, leading to the formation of 37Cl-rich urKREEP residual melts (Fig. 9).
body_text.title: LMO degassing and timing of 37Cl enrichment of urKREEP

body_text.sentence: During the analytical campaign, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and electron probe microanalysis (EPMA) were carried out in order to characterise mineral chemistry in the thin-sections studied, following the methods detailed in Barnes et al. (2014).
body_text.title: Analytical protocols

body_text.sentence: We have provided strong evidence that lunar samples obtained their exotic heavy Cl-isotopic compositions by variable incorporation of urKREEP (δ37Cl of ∼+30‰).
body_text.title: Summary

body_text.sentence: The samples studied show Cl-isotopic compositions ranging from ∼+2 to ∼+36‰, and reveal a stark difference between KREEP-poor and KREEP-rich samples.
body_text.title: Summary

body_text.sentence: Apatite 17 is enclosed within a troilite grain (Fig. 3I).
body_text.title: Petrographic context of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: In thin-section 15555,206, apatite occurs enclosed in pyroxene (type 1) or, more commonly, in contact with plagioclase, pyroxene, silica, and K-feldspar (type 2).
body_text.title: Petrographic context of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: VHK basalt 14304,177 contains interstitial K-rich areas and vein-like structures that are situated between pyroxene and plagioclase crystals.
body_text.title: Petrographic context of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: The scenario we propose to account for the elevated Cl isotope composition of urKREEP involves a large (or multiple) impact event(s) during the first 150 to 200 million years (Kamata et al., 2015) of the Moon's history, which is consistent with the requirement for post-core formation addition of highly siderophile elements (HSEs) (Day et al., 2007) and other volatiles such as H (Albarède et al., 2013; Tartèse et al., 2013; Füri et al., 2014; Hauri et al., 2015) and N (Füri et al., 2015) to the lunar mantle.
body_text.title: LMO degassing and timing of 37Cl enrichment of urKREEP

body_text.sentence: In places the K-rich veins contain K-feldspar, K-rich glass (appearing brown in plane polarised light), merrillite, baddeleyite, and apatite (an example is shown in Fig. 4A).
body_text.title: Petrographic context of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: Although the PKT does not show evidence from gravity data as being an impact basin (Andrews-Hanna et al., 2014), impacts as early as those required to expose the residual LMO liquid may not be preserved due to viscoelastic relaxation of the early hot lunar crust (e.g., Kamata et al., 2015).
body_text.title: LMO degassing and timing of 37Cl enrichment of urKREEP

body_text.sentence: Sample 76535,51 contains three crystals of apatite as reported in Barnes et al. (2014).
body_text.title: Petrographic context of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: Apatite 5 also analysed here is found between type 1 and type 2 petrographic settings (Fig. 3G) where it is most commonly enclosed in clinopyroxene as euhedral to subhedral crystals of up to ∼30 μm in the longest dimension and typically containing plagioclase inclusions.
body_text.title: Petrographic context of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: A multitude of studies have investigated the abundances of volatiles (H2O, F, and Cl, e.g., McCubbin et al., 2010a, 2010b, 2011; Boyce et al., 2010) and the hydrogen isotopic compositions of lunar apatite (e.g., Greenwood et al., 2011; Barnes et al., 2013, 2014; Tartèse et al., 2013, 2014a, 2014b; Boyce et al., 2015).
body_text.title: Introduction

body_text.sentence: Apatite 2 is subhedral and occurs as blades up to ∼100 μm in length (Fig. 4C).
body_text.title: Petrographic context of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: In summary, our model does not preclude (a) the presence of H prior to metal chloride degassing from urKREEP nor (b) the possibility of at least some degassing of H in the form of HCl and/or H2 during metal chloride loss from urKREEP.
body_text.title: LMO degassing and vapour speciation: Implications for H-isotopes

body_text.sentence: However, such signatures have yet to be observed in apatite from KREEP-rich lithologies considered to be unaffected by degassing (e.g., KREEP basalt 72275 and Mg-suite norite 78235), which implies that either in this scenario only partial (<95%) degassing of H occurred, or that the heavy degassed signature was overprinted by volatiles added by carbonaceous chondrites during late accretion (e.g., Alexander et al., 2012; Bottke et al., 2010).
body_text.title: LMO degassing and vapour speciation: Implications for H-isotopes

body_text.sentence: In the framework of Cl degassing (metal chlorides as the major Cl carrier) from urKREEP, it is likely that H was also degassed in the form of HCl and/or H2.
body_text.title: LMO degassing and vapour speciation: Implications for H-isotopes

body_text.sentence: Pahlevan and Stevenson (2007) also presented an elegant model to explain the isotopic similarity of oxygen isotopes (e.g., Wiechert et al., 2001) between the Earth and the Moon.
body_text.title: Introduction

body_text.sentence: Consequently, one would expect that samples from outside of the PKT and nearside Apollo-sampled region of the Moon to have chondritic and terrestrial-like Cl-isotopic compositions.
body_text.title: LMO degassing and timing of 37Cl enrichment of urKREEP

body_text.sentence: These H-isotope compositions are similar to those measured in the lunar picritic glasses (Saal et al., 2013; Füri et al., 2014), which have been interpreted, at least in part, as resulting from degassing of molecular H2 during ascent and emplacement of basaltic magmas on the lunar surface under reducing conditions.
body_text.title: Introduction

body_text.sentence: Apatite in sample 15386 is almost exclusively found within mesostasis pockets surrounded by plagioclase and/or pyroxene crystals.
body_text.title: Petrographic context of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: The largest apatite crystal is also found in contact with a symplectite assemblage (consisting of Mg–Al chromite and two pyroxenes, Elardo et al., 2012) and clinopyroxene (Fig. 5A, Barnes et al., 2014).
body_text.title: Petrographic context of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: If degassing of a Cl-bearing vapour was influencing the Cl-isotopic composition, then the opposite correlation would be expected (Ustunisik et al., 2011, 2015).
body_text.title: Reconciling H- and Cl-isotope measurements of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: These studies have shown that (i) parental melts to the mare basalts contained H2O > F > Cl, whilst the parent melts to the lunar highlands rocks were characterised by Cl > H2O ≈ F (McCubbin et al., 2015a), and (ii) that apatite in mare basalts were generally characterised by elevated H-isotope signatures (>+600‰, Greenwood et al., 2011; Tartèse et al., 2013).
body_text.title: Introduction

body_text.sentence: When compared to chondritic meteorites and terrestrial rocks (e.g., Sharp et al., 2013a), most lunar samples have exotic Cl isotopic compositions (Sharp et al., 2010; Treiman et al., 2014; Tartèse et al., 2014b; Boyce et al., 2015), which are difficult to explain in light of the abundance and isotopic composition of other volatile species, especially H, and the current estimates for Cl and H2O in the Bulk Silicate Moon (BSM) (Hauri et al., 2015; McCubbin et al., 2015a).
body_text.title: Introduction

body_text.sentence: Apatite in thin-section 78235,43 are either found in small pockets of mesostasis containing Fe-metal, silica, merrillite, and clinopyroxene or associated with the main rock-forming orthopyroxene and plagioclase grains.
body_text.title: Petrographic context of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: For lunar magmas, H2 is also likely to be an important degassing species (Richet et al., 1977; Ustunisik et al., 2015).
body_text.title: LMO degassing and vapour speciation: Implications for H-isotopes

body_text.sentence: However a positive correlation between Cl abundance and δ37Cl values of apatite is consistent with the assimilation of a δ37Cl-enriched component, which has also been reported recently in martian rocks (Williams et al., in press).
body_text.title: Reconciling H- and Cl-isotope measurements of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: Existing models for the formation of the Moon (Ćuk and Stewart, 2012; Canup, 2012) predict widespread melting and partial vaporisation of silicate material.
body_text.title: Introduction

body_text.sentence: In summary, there is a clear grouping between KREEP-rich rocks, such as those from the Mg-suite, KREEP basalts, and VHK basalts, characterised by elevated δ37Cl values, and less KREEPy rocks, such as the high- and low-Ti mare basalts, characterised by lower δ37Cl values.
body_text.title: Relating heavy Cl-isotopic compositions to a KREEP component

body_text.sentence: Apatite crystals range from anhedral to subhedral and range in size from ∼50 μm to ∼250 μm.
body_text.title: Petrographic context of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: However, collectively these models have yet to fully reconcile the thermal evolution of the early Moon with the presence of H2O and other associated volatile signatures in the lunar interior, that have been recognised through studies of lunar samples.
body_text.title: Introduction

body_text.sentence: These observations confirm that the KREEP component, and by extension urKREEP, was characterised by extremely heavy δ37Cl values while the mantle source regions of mare basalts had a terrestrial-like Cl-isotopic composition.
body_text.title: Relating heavy Cl-isotopic compositions to a KREEP component

body_text.sentence: Hydrodynamic escape (Pahlevan and Stevenson, 2007) may have facilitated the extensive loss of volatiles to the vacuum of space during the proto-lunar disk phase.
body_text.title: Introduction

body_text.sentence: Granulitic breccia 79215 is composed of both a matrix portion dominated by an anorthositic troctolite composition and a troctolitic portion.
body_text.title: Petrographic context of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: In fact, it has recently been demonstrated experimentally that during ascent of volatile-rich magmas, hydrogen is likely to be the earliest volatile to degas, and after H is depleted in the melt, Cl becomes the preferred volatile that is lost (Sharp et al., 2013b; Ustunisik et al., 2015), supporting the requirement for very low H/Cl ratios in magmas at the time of Cl degassing.
body_text.title: Reconciling H- and Cl-isotope measurements of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: Hydrogen and chlorine are both incompatible elements that are soluble in silicate melts (Cl more so than H), so it is reasonable to assume that both would be concentrated in urKREEP (e.g., review by McCubbin et al., 2015a).
body_text.title: LMO degassing and vapour speciation: Implications for H-isotopes

body_text.sentence: In this sample, the apatite crystals are restricted to the K-rich regions and typically range from ∼50 to >300 μm in the longest dimension.
body_text.title: Petrographic context of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: Furthermore, the H/Cl ratio of urKREEP is reported to be <1 (McCubbin et al., 2015a).
body_text.title: LMO degassing and vapour speciation: Implications for H-isotopes

body_text.sentence: Apatite in this section is very rare and occurs mostly in mesostasis areas in contact with K-feldspar and silica.
body_text.title: Petrographic context of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: To achieve this, we have measured the Cl-isotopic compositions of apatite in a diverse range of lunar samples, ranging in lithologies from mare basalts, to KREEP and VHK basalts and pristine highlands samples.
body_text.title: Summary

body_text.sentence: Apatite Cl contents were calibrated using the measured 35Cl/18O ratios and the known Cl contents of terrestrial apatite standards (described in McCubbin et al., 2010a, 2012), which were pressed into an indium mount along with a San Carlos olivine crystal that was used to estimate background abundances of H2O (between ∼10 and 90 ppm) and Cl (<5 ppm).
body_text.title: Analytical protocols

body_text.sentence: We observed apatite in contact with either late-stage K-feldspar, silica and other phases (e.g., Fig. 3D) or in contact with plagioclase, pyroxene, and a symplectite assemblage (e.g., Fig. 3E).
body_text.title: Petrographic context of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: In order to fully understand the meaning and significance of the unique Cl-isotope compositions displayed by the majority of lunar rocks and to place these in the context of the differentiation of the Moon, we investigated the Cl-isotopic composition of apatite from a diverse set of lunar samples from Apollo missions: 11 (10044 & 10058), 14 (14304), 15 (15386 & 15555), and 17 (70035, 76535, 78235 & 79215).
body_text.title: Introduction

body_text.sentence: Apatite 1 analysed in this work is in the type 2 location (Fig. 3F) where it forms acicular rods of up to 100 μm in length.
body_text.title: Petrographic context of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: We hypothesise that the differentiation of the Moon via a LMO provides the most elegant mechanism for concentrating volatiles, especially Cl, into a residual melt (urKREEP).
body_text.title: Summary

body_text.sentence: In the context of the lunar magma ocean (LMO) model, late-stage LMO residual melts are thought to have been enriched in incompatible elements such as K, REEs, and P, which are collectively called urKREEP or a KREEP-component, when referred to as a geochemical reservoir or geochemical component, respectively (Warren and Wasson, 1979).
body_text.title: Introduction

body_text.sentence: Each crystal co-exists with merrillite and is located between plagioclase crystals.
body_text.title: Petrographic context of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: The crystal is enclosed in mesostasis glass and troilite.
body_text.title: Petrographic context of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: The LMO period in the Moon's evolution is highly unlikely to have been quiescent and it has been proposed by many (e.g., Day et al., 2007; Bottke et al., 2010; Kamata et al., 2015) that impactors were accreting to the Moon during the LMO phase (Fig. 9).
body_text.title: LMO degassing and vapour speciation: Implications for H-isotopes

body_text.sentence: Given the spatial association of the Apollo sampling sites and the Procellarum KREEP Terrane (PKT), the surface expression of KREEP is presumably represented by the PKT region (Jolliff et al., 2000).
body_text.title: LMO degassing and timing of 37Cl enrichment of urKREEP

body_text.sentence: Any degassing of H in the form of HCl or H2 would result in similar H and D fractionations (Richet et al., 1977), as calculated by Tartèse et al. (2013) (Supplementary Fig. 2).
body_text.title: LMO degassing and vapour speciation: Implications for H-isotopes

body_text.sentence: Apatite 2 is found in contact with K-feldspar, ilmenite, and pyroxene, and it surrounds a pocket of K-feldspar.
body_text.title: Petrographic context of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: A model in which urKREEP was exposed to high vacuum subsequent to the formation of the anorthosite crust, after the dissipation of the LMO atmosphere, circumvents all three of the potential issues raised above with the Boyce et al. (2015) model of early LMO degassing of metal chlorides.
body_text.title: LMO degassing and timing of 37Cl enrichment of urKREEP

body_text.sentence: In any case, it is likely that variations of apatite δD and δ37Cl values have resulted from the interplay between different magmatic processes such as degassing or mixing, potentially overprinting of any geochemical signatures inherited from previously-formed isotopic reservoirs.
body_text.title: Reconciling H- and Cl-isotope measurements of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: Fig. 8A shows a strong positive correlation between apatite δ37Cl values and La/Sm ratios (La/Smn), which strongly indicates mixing between a mantle source with low δ37Cl isotopic composition (∼0‰, Y-intercept in Fig. 8A) and a KREEP-rich component characterised by a δ37Cl value ∼+30‰.
body_text.title: Relating heavy Cl-isotopic compositions to a KREEP component

body_text.sentence: The current estimates for the H-isotopic composition of H2O in urKREEP range from as low as −400 to +200‰ (Barnes et al., 2014; Tartèse et al., 2014a).
body_text.title: LMO degassing and vapour speciation: Implications for H-isotopes

body_text.sentence: It is anticipated that chlorine (and other volatiles) should have been concentrated in the residual LMO melts given its incompatibility in olivine and pyroxene, which were the dominant early phases to crystallise in the cumulate pile of the LMO (e.g., Snyder et al., 1992; Elkins-Tanton et al., 2002, 2011; Elkins-Tanton and Grove, 2011; Elardo et al., 2011).
body_text.title: Introduction

body_text.sentence: If the lowest measured δD value of highlands apatite is considered as the pre-degassing urKREEP signature (77215, ∼−400‰, Barnes et al., 2014), then the observations from KREEPy lithologies can be reconciled with differential (0 to 99%) degassing of H2 and/or HCl (Supplementary Fig. 2).
body_text.title: LMO degassing and vapour speciation: Implications for H-isotopes

body_text.sentence: If the pre-degassing H-isotopic composition of H in urKREEP was heavier than ∼−400‰, for example −200 or 0‰, then 99% degassing of H2 would increase the δD value to >+400–500‰.
body_text.title: LMO degassing and vapour speciation: Implications for H-isotopes

body_text.sentence: Apatite 10 is a subhedral crystal that is ∼25 μm in the longest dimension occurring inter-grown with merrillite.
body_text.title: Petrographic context of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: All of the apatite crystals are anhedral to subhedral and range from ∼30 to >300 μm in the longest dimension (Fig. 5C).
body_text.title: Petrographic context of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: The aims of this study were to (i) thoroughly investigate the apparently unique Cl isotope compositions of lunar samples, (ii) to reconcile new and existing H and Cl data for lunar samples in order to identify potential volatile reservoirs within the Moon, and (iii) to assess the requirement for early Cl degassing from the lunar magma ocean as predicted by previous work.
body_text.title: Summary

body_text.sentence: In order to account for the Cl-isotopic composition of urKREEP, this residual melt had to degas following enrichment at relatively low pressures, and for this we invoke puncturing of the lunar crust by one or several large impact events, prior to the solidification of the urKREEP liquid in the LMO.
body_text.title: Summary

body_text.sentence: Apatite is abundant in this thin-section of sample 79215, occurring exclusively in the troctolite portion and in direct contact with olivine, plagioclase, and troilite.
body_text.title: Petrographic context of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: Consequently, we envisage a scenario in which during the latter stages of LMO crystallisation (>95%), a large bolide, or series of bolides, punctured the lunar crust (Kamata et al., 2015) to a depth sufficient to expose the Cl-rich urKREEP layer, or bring KREEP-rich melts up to the strong vacuum at the lunar surface, which initiated degassing of metal chlorides (Sharp et al., 2010).
body_text.title: LMO degassing and timing of 37Cl enrichment of urKREEP

body_text.sentence: We further investigated whether the heavy Cl-isotope signature could be related to the proportion of KREEP component in lunar samples by correlating Cl isotope compositions with bulk-rock incompatible trace element (La, Sm and ε143Nd initial) data (Supplementary Table 2).
body_text.title: Relating heavy Cl-isotopic compositions to a KREEP component

body_text.sentence: It is important to consider the possibility that H degassing could have occurred simultaneously with Cl loss.
body_text.title: LMO degassing and vapour speciation: Implications for H-isotopes

body_text.sentence: Importantly, if exogenous addition of volatiles to the Moon from objects with H/Cl ratios >1 (i.e., comets and carbonaceous asteroids) occurred, then it did not cause the resultant H/Cl ratio of the LMO residual liquid to exceed 1.
body_text.title: LMO degassing and vapour speciation: Implications for H-isotopes

body_text.sentence: If it had then this would have inhibited the fractionation of Cl in the LMO (discussed further in the next section).

body_text.sentence: Such low initial δD values are consistent with recently proposed values for the Earth's upper mantle (Sharp et al., 2013b; Hallis et al., 2015) or for some evolved lithologies from the Moon (Robinson et al., 2014).

body_text.sentence: Apatite 5 is an anhedral grain ∼250 μm in length that is in direct contact with merrillite, plagioclase and K-feldspar (Fig. 4D).

body_text.sentence: Texturally, the apatite contains rounded blebs of pre-existing plagioclase and olivine, with lobate crystal edges.

body_text.sentence: Therefore, it is not unreasonable to assume that some of these impactors contributed H2O to the lunar interior during differentiation or after urKREEP degassing (e.g., Bottke et al., 2010) (Fig. 9 and calculations in the Supplementary Material).
body_text.title: LMO degassing and vapour speciation: Implications for H-isotopes

body_text.sentence: In addition, the effects of HCl degassing from basaltic melts on the fractionation of Cl isotopes has never been investigated under conditions relevant to mare basalt petrogenesis (e.g., low oxygen fugacity under vacuum), adding to the complexity of interpreting combined apatite δD and δ37Cl values.

body_text.sentence: However, it remains unclear whether successive episodes of volatile-degassing from a single magma could explain both elevated δD and elevated δ37Cl values measured in apatite in mare basalts.

body_text.sentence: As stated above, there is a positive correlation between apatite Cl contents and associated isotopic composition in KREEP basalt 15386.
body_text.title: Reconciling H- and Cl-isotope measurements of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: Currently, it has been argued that only a few samples (olivine-hosted melt inclusions trapped within picritic glass beads, some KREEP basalts and a few plutonic highlands rocks) may have preserved primitive lunar H-isotopic compositions (Saal et al., 2013; Barnes et al., 2014; Tartèse et al., 2014a).
body_text.title: Introduction

body_text.sentence: Apatite occurs as subhedral grains up to ∼95 μm in length and are generally heavily cracked (Fig. 5B).
body_text.title: Petrographic context of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: In thin-section 10058,254, apatite is commonly found in late-stage mesostasis areas comprised of K-rich phases (K-feldspar and occasionally K-rich glass), troilite, baddeleyite, pyroxene, silica, Fe-pyroxene, tranquillityite, ilmenite, fayalite, and a symplectite assemblage.
body_text.title: Petrographic context of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: Indeed, the requirements of very low H/Cl ratios in the melt to account for the elevated δ37Cl values measured, which was proposed by Sharp et al. (2010), seems incompatible with the occurrence of OH-rich apatite relative to Cl in the mare basalts (Tartèse et al., 2013; McCubbin et al., 2015a) given the relative preference of Cl over H into crystallising apatite (Boyce et al., 2014; McCubbin et al., 2015b), which should result in very OH-poor apatite (Ustunisik et al., 2015).
body_text.title: Reconciling H- and Cl-isotope measurements of lunar apatite

body_text.sentence: High-precision in situ measurements of Cl-isotopes and volatiles in apatite from the following nine Apollo thin-sections were carried out in this work: 10044,645; 10058,254; 14304,177; 15386,46; 15555,206; 70035,195; 76535,51; 78235,43 and 79215,50.

body_text.sentence: The uncertainties reported on the Cl contents of the ‘unknown’ apatite combine the 2σ uncertainty associated with the calibrations and the analytical uncertainties associated with each individual measurement.
